newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn, Bundesbank want timely EMU-Buba's Schmidhuber.
newsitem.headline: Bonn, Bundesbank want timely EMU-Buba's Schmidhuber.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Peter Schmidhuber said on Friday both the German government and central bank were committed to a punctual start for European economic and monetary union (EMU) in 1999.

"The government and the Bundesbank are committed to a punctual start for EMU on January 1, 1999," Schmidhuber said in the text of a speech to be delivered to the Federation of the German Chemical Industry in Hamburg.
"The federal government, regional states and local authorities are making considerable efforts to ensure that Germany fulfills all the convergence criteria," he said.

The sheer size of the challenge to those nations participating in the project meant that it would "not be detrimental" if, as might yet happen, only a small number of nations could take part on time, he added.

Stressing the need for long-term stability of the public finances of participating nations, Schmidhuber said it could be harmful if sanctions within the proposed stability pact needed to be applied to countries directly after EMU's start.

"The currency union would lose a great deal of credibility if, soon after the start of EMU, the stability pact had to be activated in respect of participants which had not made sufficient progress in consolidating their budgets," he said.
